title: World History
description: Test your knowledge of major events that shaped our world — from ancient times to the modern era!

questions.question: Which ancient wonder of the world was located in the city of Babylon?
questions.explanation: The Hanging Gardens of Babylon were one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, reportedly built by King Nebuchadnezzar II around 600 BC.

questions.question: The Magna Carta, a foundational document for modern democracy, was signed in which year?
questions.explanation: The Magna Carta was sealed by King John of England in 1215 at Runnymede. It limited royal authority and established that even the king was subject to law.

questions.question: Which empire was the largest contiguous land empire in history?
questions.explanation: The Mongol Empire, founded by Genghis Khan in 1206, stretched from Eastern Europe to the Sea of Japan at its peak, covering about 24 million square kilometers.

questions.question: The Renaissance began in which country during the 14th century?
questions.explanation: The Renaissance began in Italy, particularly in Florence, during the 14th century. Wealthy patrons like the Medici family helped fuel this cultural rebirth.

questions.question: Which treaty ended World War I?
questions.explanation: The Treaty of Versailles was signed on June 28, 1919. It imposed heavy reparations on Germany and redrew the map of Europe.

questions.question: Who was the first Emperor of China, unifying the country in 221 BC?
questions.explanation: Qin Shi Huang unified China and began construction of the Great Wall. He is also famous for his terracotta army buried with him.

questions.question: The Black Death pandemic in the 14th century is estimated to have killed what proportion of Europe's population?
questions.explanation: The Black Death (bubonic plague) killed an estimated one-third of Europe's population between 1347 and 1351, roughly 25 million people.

questions.question: Which event in 1789 is considered the start of the French Revolution?
questions.explanation: The Storming of the Bastille on July 14, 1789 is widely considered the symbolic start of the French Revolution. Bastille Day is still celebrated in France.

questions.question: The ancient city of Pompeii was buried by the eruption of which volcano in 79 AD?
questions.explanation: Mount Vesuvius erupted on August 24, 79 AD, burying Pompeii under volcanic ash. The preserved ruins provide an incredible snapshot of Roman life.

questions.question: Which explorer led the first expedition to successfully circumnavigate the globe?
questions.explanation: Ferdinand Magellan organized the expedition in 1519, though he was killed in the Philippines. Juan Sebastián Elcano completed the voyage in 1522.

questions.question: The Berlin Wall fell in which year, symbolizing the end of the Cold War?
questions.explanation: The Berlin Wall fell on November 9, 1989. East and West Germany were officially reunified on October 3, 1990.

questions.question: Which civilization built Machu Picchu high in the Andes Mountains?
questions.explanation: Machu Picchu was built by the Inca civilization around 1450 AD. It sits at about 7,970 feet above sea level in modern-day Peru.

questions.question: The Rosetta Stone, key to deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphics, was discovered during whose military campaign?
questions.explanation: The Rosetta Stone was found by French soldiers during Napoleon's Egyptian campaign in 1799. It was later deciphered by Jean-François Champollion in 1822.

questions.question: Which country was the first to grant women the right to vote in national elections?
questions.explanation: New Zealand became the first self-governing country to grant all women the right to vote in 1893, over 25 years before the United States.

questions.question: The ancient Library of Alexandria, one of the greatest libraries of the ancient world, was located in which modern country?
questions.explanation: The Library of Alexandria was in Egypt, founded in the 3rd century BC. It aimed to collect all the world's knowledge and may have held up to 400,000 scrolls.

questions.question: Which war lasted from 1337 to 1453, making it one of the longest conflicts in history?
questions.explanation: The Hundred Years' War was a series of conflicts between England and France lasting 116 years. Joan of Arc played a key role in the French victory.

questions.question: Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for how many years before becoming South Africa's first Black president?
questions.explanation: Nelson Mandela was imprisoned from 1964 to 1990 — 27 years. He became president in 1994 after South Africa's first fully democratic election.

questions.question: The Silk Road was an ancient trade network connecting China to which region?
questions.explanation: The Silk Road connected China to the Mediterranean, facilitating trade in silk, spices, gold, and ideas for over 1,500 years.

questions.question: Which event in 1066 changed the course of English history?
questions.explanation: William the Conqueror defeated King Harold at the Battle of Hastings in 1066, beginning Norman rule of England and transforming English culture and language.

questions.question: The United Nations was founded in which year?
questions.explanation: The United Nations was established on October 24, 1945, after World War II. It was founded with 51 member states and now has 193.
